intro: Calculate your exact take-home pay in the United Kingdom with our comprehensive 2024/25 tax calculator. Includes progressive income tax, National Insurance contributions, student loan repayments, Scottish tax variations, and pension relief. Perfect for tax planning and salary negotiations.

ui.noResultsText: Enter your salary details to calculate take-home pay

howItWorks: This UK salary calculator uses 2025/26 tax rates and bands. We calculate your personal allowance, apply progressive tax rates, include National Insurance contributions, deduct student loan repayments if applicable, and account for regional variations (Scotland, Wales). All calculations follow HMRC guidelines.

example.scenario: A 28-year-old graduate earns £45,000 in England with Plan 2 student loan and £5,000 pension contributions.
example.results: Income tax: £6,432 | NI: £3,764 | Student loan: £1,561 | Net take-home: £33,243 | Monthly: £2,770

faqs.question: Are these calculations accurate for 2025/26?
faqs.answer: Yes, we use official 2025/26 tax bands, National Insurance rates, and student loan thresholds from HMRC.

faqs.question: Does this include Scottish tax rates?
faqs.answer: Yes, select 'Scotland' to use Scottish tax bands which differ from the rest of the UK.

faqs.question: How are student loans calculated?
faqs.answer: We use the official HMRC student loan repayment thresholds and rates for Plan 1, Plan 2, and Postgraduate loans.

faqs.question: Are pension contributions tax-deductible?
faqs.answer: Yes, pre-tax pension contributions reduce your taxable income and are included in the calculations.

faqs.question: What's the difference between personal allowance and tax-free amount?
faqs.answer: The personal allowance is the amount you can earn before paying income tax. It varies by age group.
